27.text: Hello. Another bout of intellectual Buckaroo lies ahead of us tonight

32.text: as we play the last of the first-round matches

36.text: So far, Magdalen College, Oxford and the universities of Manchester

39.text: and Sheffield have earned themselves places in the semifinals.

43.text: If tonight's winners are to go through and join them,

45.text: they need to beat University College London's score of 155.

49.text: Now, first tonight, the team from the University of Durham.

52.text: We pride ourselves on this programme that this series is one of the few

55.text: occasions when librarians get the recognition they deserve,

58.text: and Durham's first team member has worked in the libraries

62.text: of the House of Lords and Edinburgh University,

64.text: as well as the National Library of Scotland.

66.text: He is the 25th incumbent of his current post,

72.text: With him, a news presenter and reporter who,

74.text: in the past 20 years, has covered stories both in studio

78.text: and on location, from the crisis in Ukraine

80.text: to the rescue of the Chilean miners,

82.text: the uprisings of the Arab spring and the Japanese tsunami.

86.text: Their captain is a leading space scientist.

89.text: She has headed the Meteorite team at the Natural History Museum

93.text: and in 2014 she was the world's cheerleader when the Philae probe

97.text: became the first spacecraft to land on a comet nucleus.

101.text: Joining them is a Dutch-born entrepreneur

103.text: who in 2000 founded an institution which has attracted 16 million

107.text: visitors and brought over £1 billion into the Cornish economy.

115.text: I graduated from Durham in 1985, in modern history and economic history.

120.text: I'm now Bodley's Librarian, which means I'm responsible

122.text: for the research libraries of the University of Oxford.

126.text: I'm Tim Willcox. I read Spanish at Durham

130.text: Since then, I've been working as a journalist in newspapers then TV.

134.text: I currently work as a presenter for BBC News.

140.text: I read chemistry and geology at St Aidan's College, Durham,

144.text: I'm currently Professor of Planetary and Space Sciences

149.text: My name is Tim Smit. I graduated in 1976 from Durham,

155.text: But today I lead the Eden Project

157.text: and the Lost Gardens of Heligan in Cornwall.

165.text: Their opponents are playing for the London School of Economics.

168.text: Its founders in 1895 included Sidney and Beatrice Webb

172.text: and George Bernard Shaw, and the four trying not to let them down

175.text: tonight include a former criminal law barrister turned Conservative MP.

180.text: He's been Shadow Minister for London, local government minister

185.text: With him, a journalist who has spent eight years as the

189.text: He left that job to take up his present role, of

192.text: which he said that it was "the only one that could have lured him away -

195.text: "and if it goes wrong, he'll be on the next plane back."

199.text: Their captain is an award-winning campaigner, newspaper columnist,

203.text: and writer on all things to do with personal finances.

206.text: He presents his own programme on ITV,

208.text: is the resident expert on numerous other programmes,

210.text: and is executive chairman of the UK's biggest money website.

215.text: Their fourth team member began his career as one of the youngest

218.text: show business editors in Fleet Street.

220.text: Since then he's written for the Times Literary Supplement

223.text: and The Guardian, but is best known for presenting numerous radio

226.text: and television programmes. Let's meet the LSE team.

230.text: Hi, I'm Bob Neill. I read law at LSE in the 1970s.

233.text: Now I'm the MP for Bromley and Chislehurst

236.text: and Chair of Parliament's Justice Select Committee.

241.text: I took a degree in economics in 1983.

243.text: Now I present the Today programme on Radio Four.

249.text: I graduated in government and law in 1994.

252.text: I've since founded and run moneysavingexpert.com.

255.text: This is Felix, the LSE Beaver.

261.text:
- with a gift for double entendre. 
- LAUGHTER

263.text: Hello, I'm James O'Brien. I graduated in 1995

269.text: I'm now a journalist and broadcaster with a daily show on LBC radio.

278.text: OK, you all know the rules, I guess. If you don't, you shouldn't be here.

282.text: So let's just crack on with it, shall we?

284.text: Fingers on the buzzers, here's your first starter for ten.

288.text: what six-letter adjective may proceed the words

291.text: stick, bean, horn, cricket, mustard, dressing, toast...?

301.text: Right, Durham. Your bonuses are on a work of literature.

307.text: Which short novel of 1843 did the Illustrated London News note -

311.text: "the surpassing beauty with which they accomplished

314.text: "author of this seasonable little volume has worked out - or,

317.text: "as he supportively terms it, raised 'the ghost of an idea'"?

325.text: After reading A Christmas Carol, which notoriously

330.text: and essayist was seized with a perfect convulsion of hospitality

335.text: and hosted two festive dinner parties at his Cheyne Walk residence?

342.text: To which character in a Christmas Carol

346.text: he wrote, "There is not a reader in England but that little creature will

349.text: "be a bond of union between the author and him"?

362.text: formerly attributed to Dionysius the Aeropagite,

365.text: was an important influence on which 13th-century theologian?

371.text: his works included the Summa Theologica.

378.text: Your bonuses are on Jewish religious festivals, Durham.

382.text: Originally an agricultural festival marking the start of the summer

385.text: wheat harvest, Shavuot, or the Festival of the Weeks,

389.text: is also known by what name, from the Greek meaning 50th?

404.text: Translated into English as the Feast of Lots, which festival

407.text: commemorates the survival of the Jews who, according to the Book of Esther,

411.text: were marked for death by the Persian rulers in the 5th century BC?

423.text: And finally, thought to derive from the Hebrew verb meaning to dedicate,

426.text: what name denotes the festival celebrated over eight days,

429.text: and also known as the Feast of Dedication,

432.text: the Feast of Lights and the Feast of the Maccabees?

437.text:
- Hanukkah. 
- Correct. Ten points for this.

439.text: Who was the subject of Andrew Robinson's 2006 biography

443.text: entitled The Last Man Who Knew Everything?

445.text: A physician and physicist born in Somerset in 1773,

449.text: he established the principle of interference of light,

452.text: and was instrumental in deciphering the Rosetta Stone.

462.text: Your bonuses are on scientific theories later disproved, Durham.

469.text: an early chemical theory assumed that all combustible material

472.text: was in part composed of which hypothetical substance?

476.text: The idea was discredited by Lavoisier from 1770.

480.text: Correct. What name was given to the weightless, transparent,

483.text: frictionless substance thought to permeate all matter and space,

487.text: until the Michelson-Morley experiment of 1881 severely

490.text: weakened the theory of its existence.

493.text: Correct. And finally, work by Wegener in 1912 was the first rigorous

499.text: attempt to refute the idea that the major landmasses of the Earth were

502.text: immovable. This view persisted until the 1960s,

506.text: when what theory became generally accepted?

510.text: Or continental drift, yes. Right, a picture round now.

514.text: you are going to see a map showing

516.text: the locations of the host venues

522.text: For ten points, I want you to

533.text: It is the ICC Cricket World Cup. Well done.

545.text: and the name of its cricket ground at which World Cup matches were played.

549.text: Firstly, the city and cricket ground at A.

563.text: It is Brisbane. It's the Gabba though, the cricket ground.

565.text: Secondly, the city and the cricket ground at B.

572.text: Do we know the cricket ground at Auckland?

576.text: Auckland and the Auckland Cricket Ground.

581.text: And finally, the city and cricket ground at C.

585.text:
- That's Sydney, isn't it? 
- The MCC. Or is it Melbourne?

595.text: It's Melbourne and the MCG. The Melbourne Cricket Ground.

599.text: Oh, actually, you can have it. Why not?

608.text: recent work by the British political economist Mark Blyth?

611.text: The single-word title denotes a particular approach to

623.text: Three questions on carol singing for your bonuses, LSE.

626.text: In each case, give the title of the literary work

628.text: from which the following lines are taken.

633.text: "There had been singing under the windows after midnight -

638.text: "in spite of Tom's contemptuous insistence that the singers

642.text: "were Old Patch, the parish clerk, and the rest of the church choir."

648.text: No, it's from The Mill On The Floss by George Eliot.

653.text: "For a year we had praised the Lord, out of key,

656.text: "and as a reward for this service we now had the right to visit

660.text: "all the big houses, to sing our carols and collect our tribute."

674.text: That's from Cider With Rosie by Laurie Lee.

676.text: And finally, from a 1908 novel for children.

678.text: "As the door opened, one of the elder ones that carried

681.text: "the lantern was just saying, 'Now then - one, two, three!'

684.text: "And forthwith their shrill little voices uprose on the air

687.text: "singing one of the old-time carols that their forefathers composed."

696.text:
- No, it's The Wind In The Willows. 
- Wind In The Willows!

699.text: Ten points for this. Listen carefully.

701.text: Benjamin Disraeli described idiosyncrasy is a quality

703.text: "which ought never to be possessed by an Archbishop of Canterbury,

708.text: What is the dictionary spelling of the word idiosyncrasy?

747.text: is a later work by which author, who died in 1992?

750.text: Perhaps best-known for French provincial cooking,

754.text: she has been described as "the best writer on food and drink..."

763.text: LSE, you get questions on Iris Murdoch and philosophy.

767.text: "People were liberated by that book after the war,

770.text: "it made people happy, it was like the Gospel."

776.text: a work by which French philosopher?

786.text: Correct. Iris Murdoch's 1977 work The Fire And The Sun discusses the

791.text: attitude to art and the theory of beauty of which ancient philosopher?

800.text: Plato seems more likely, doesn't he?

805.text: In the 1959 essay The Sublime And The Good,

807.text: what concept did Iris Murdoch described as "the extremely

811.text: "difficult realisation that something other than oneself is real"?

825.text: Which three cautionary words link a 1968 recording by the sound

829.text: engineer Peter Lodge, the voice artist Emma Clarke, and The Archers

833.text: actor Tim Bentinck, who has been heard on the Piccadilly Line?

843.text: Right, three questions on checkmates in chess for your bonuses, LSE.

847.text: Scholar's mate is a checkmate that may often catch out a beginner,

850.text: and always results in a win after how many moves?

859.text:
- Six or eight. 
- I think it's three.

868.text: No, it's four. It's also known as the four-move checkmate.

872.text: Involving a queen with a bishop, checkmating the opposing king.

878.text: what term describes a checkmate by knight against a king that

881.text: has all of its escape squares blocked by its own pieces?

885.text: The term suggests being surrounded and unable to breathe.

898.text: And finally, Anastasia's mate and Arabian mate most commonly involve

902.text: which two pieces working in tandem to checkmate the opposing king?

906.text: It would be a horse, wouldn't it?

913.text: No, it's a knight and a rook.

938.text: # Look at yourselves in a ghost town... #

959.text: No, it's Madonna. It's Ghost Town.

961.text: Music bonuses in a moment or two.

973.text: They form part of the surface of the vitreous body.

1241.text: Correct. No Plan Like Yours To Study History Wisely

1584.text: Ten points for this. Listen carefully.

1595.text: Stimulated. I'll accept that. You've got the right idea.

1600.text: Right, your bonuses are on fictional doctors.

1603.text: The former Nazi, Dr Christian Szell,

1613.text: refers to the image of the eyes of Dr TJ Ekelberg?

1628.text: Right, at the gong, it's absolutely level pegging.

1631.text: The way we are going to sort this out now is

1633.text: I'm going to ask you a starter question.

1636.text: If you get it right, you get ten points and immediately win.

1639.text: If you interrupt incorrectly and get it wrong...

1645.text: ..you are fined five points and you automatically lose.

1649.text: Listen up then. Fingers on the buzzers.

1667.text: Gunter Grass is correct. That means you win.

1677.text: Well, I thought you were going to do it, LSE,

1680.text: but you need to bone up a bit on one or two subjects, I think.

1686.text: I'm afraid although you have won on 140 points, it is

1689.text: not one of the four highest winning scores.

1692.text: So we shan't be seeing you again.

1694.text: It means you have the honour of winning

1700.text: We now know the teams in the semifinal stage of the competition.

1712.text: Until then though, it's goodbye from the LSE.
